The node claims 'the Phi^4_3 measure mu is defined on the ENHANCED data space X, not merely on distributions phi. All concentration inequalities for mu therefore apply to functionals of the full enhanced data (phi, :phi^2:, :phi^3:).'

This is misleading and the second sentence is a non-sequitur. The Phi^4_3 measure mu is primarily constructed as a probability measure on the distribution space D'(T^3) (or C^{-1/2-delta}). The enhanced data (phi, :phi^2:, :phi^3:) provides a LIFTING of the measure to the product space X, in the sense that one can push forward mu to a measure on X by the map phi -> (phi, :phi^2:_mu, :phi^3:_mu). But concentration inequalities for mu (such as sub-Gaussian tails from BG 2020) are proven for functionals of phi with respect to the Cameron-Martin structure, NOT for arbitrary functionals on X. The sentence 'All concentration inequalities for mu therefore apply to functionals of the full enhanced data' is false: a concentration inequality depends on the metric/gradient structure, and extending from functionals of phi to functionals of (phi, :phi^2:, :phi^3:) requires proof that the Wick power components inherit the concentration, which is exactly the unproven claim in node 1.6.2.7.
